As written, I don't really think this can go forward.  It seems like a pretty blatant breakage of the redfish spec, and defeats a lot of the concrete purpose of abstracting the Redfish interface.

With that said, I'm interested in what the community thinks here, and there's a discussion to be had if the spec is too restrictive, but I don't see this patchset starting that discussion.

Patch Set 9:

(5 comments)
There's no need to include the old test results.  They just clutter things up.
Removed old test results...

I think this check was added for properties that are required or needed for the LogEntry to be useful (message). I am kind of guessing here though. 
Why should resolution be here?

            "required": [
                "EntryType",
                "@odata.id",
                "@odata.type",
                "Id",
                "Name"

Resolution should not be nullptr since it is part of
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/39bdb4711855ed9caf18b55427691c80e8e8ac8e/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Logging/Entry.interface.yaml#L37

and that is the interface we are looking for 
                            if (interfaceMap.first ==
                                "xyz.openbmc_project.Logging.Entry")

so I guess I am okay with this.. just seems like this expands this check to be for all properties in https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/39bdb4711855ed9caf18b55427691c80e8e8ac8e/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Logging/Entry.interface.yaml#L37

> I think this check was added for properties that are required or needed for the LogEntry to be useful (message). I am kind of guessing here though. 
> Why should resolution be here?
> 
>             "required": [
>                 "EntryType",
>                 "@odata.id",
>                 "@odata.type",
>                 "Id",
>                 "Name"
> 
> Resolution should not be nullptr since it is part of
> https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/39bdb4711855ed9caf18b55427691c80e8e8ac8e/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Logging/Entry.interface.yaml#L37

Considering that the initial version of Entry didn't have that, lets do our best to not require it, especially considering it's less code to not require it, and there's other fields that we already don't check.  id, message, and severity are explicitly checked here because they're required by the redfish schema, so we prefer to return Internal error rather than produce an incorrect redfish schema.  Resolution is not required, so it shouldn't be in this check.

> 
> and that is the interface we are looking for 
>                             if (interfaceMap.first ==
>                                 "xyz.openbmc_project.Logging.Entry")
> 
> so I guess I am okay with this.. just seems like this expands this check to be for all properties in https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/39bdb4711855ed9caf18b55427691c80e8e8ac8e/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Logging/Entry.interface.yaml#L37

I have seen in some cases on HW a different version of code the interface "xyz.openbmc_project.Logging.Entry" did not have resolution property. In that case access in line 1495 would crash system. The intent is to check it here since line 1426 will not be executed. I can move this check to line 1495 if that is OK? but I want to check for the validity of nullptr
Yeah, I would be okay with this line on 1495 / 1651
Check for validity right before the dereference, no need to set internal error to do that.
Done

We typically don't check for empty.. 
Why do you need to here?
This is an interesting question;  How do you know the difference between "Resolution not populated for this log" and "Resolution not supported"?

The reason I put the check in here is to make sure we don't return empty string. When I ran the validator it gave me warning saying value is empty and check for spelling. Also this aligns with what we discussed on ServiceProviderNotify property. If the property is not supported then we don't return it. In this case it is not populated. Not all PEL's have resolution field populated. @ed, the value is empty by default and I assume no one populated the value or in a system which does not support i we would read back empty string. I am open to suggestions here

We typically just put the property out even if it is empty. 
I guess I don't understand the difference from this and 
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/38044

Resolution is a property on the interface, so put it out on Redfish. 

If it isn't supported then 
"Then that interface needs split up into interfaces that are fully implementable".

All that said, I could live with an empty check
Done
Why the check for empty?

Validator gives the following warning:
"WARNING - Resolution: Empty string found - Services should omit properties if not supported"

Added this check to avoid that warning...
I think we should have the empty check for company's/ service's /log entries that don't support this.
Done

Isn't this breaking the redfish spec?  The registry is supposed to be usable by services that don't want to/aren't able to parse text results from a system.  Allowing to override the message registry removes this ability, and in this case largely just seems like a trapdoor to defeat the type safety of the message registry.

I suspect your path here is to add new specific message types for your various resolution strings.
@gmills or @ed, need some help here as I don't know exactly what it is breaking, and way to address...

paraphrased from what I heard a redfish co-chair: 

Resolution property is a free-form string intended only for humans to read.

Have a look at Redfish #5057 and #4440
Ack

Message is supposed to be human readable, this is not.

Also, we should not be exposing openbmc specific internal interfaces out to a spec-defined interface, as it removes our ability to modify the internal interfaces later, and essentially makes the internal interfaces external interfaces.
this has always been what the 'DBUS LOG' section in bmcweb log_services.hpp did.  Eventually we hope to improve it.

What is the plan here? 
While I understand the issue, but it is not the side effect of adding 'Resolution' property. So, not sure what is expected.
Any changes to Message seems beyond this commit.
Ack

This is in no way how this should be formatted, and seems to be embedding yet another message within the Resolution field, which is not how the resolution field works.  Resolution should be human readable, and match the registry.  If you need extra fields, embed them in your message with message args.
This is what the DMTF told us to do when we asked for how to get a list of 'callouts' into a log entry, specifically to cram a list of things into the Resolution string.
Can you point me to that conversation?  It doesn't seem in line with the redfish spec, but it's quite possible I'm wrong.
It was in a meeting.  @Gunnar - know if there was any record?

Yeah in a Redfish meeting, we (Matt and I) explained we might have "multiple resolutions" and Redfish said, it is a free form string meant to be read by a human so if you truly have multiple "how to resolve the situation that caused the log entry" then it is appropriate they are all in there. 

That said, not sure what is going on with the \n in here, also this is a pretty standard Redfish property so this seems like a bad example since it is very company specific.. Can we just use a generic, better example for the Resolution string "Check manager network.", "Replace failing Dimm.", etc ?

> Yeah in a Redfish meeting, we (Matt and I) explained we might have "multiple resolutions" and Redfish said, it is a free form string meant to be read by a human so if you truly have multiple "how to resolve the situation that caused the log entry" then it is appropriate they are all in there. 

Yes, it's a freeform string, but that doesn't mean it doesn't need to have a message registry entry for each element, or can contain variable data that doesn't match the MessageId entry.  That's different than what I'm pointing out here.

> 
> That said, not sure what is going on with the \n in here, also this is a pretty standard Redfish property so this seems like a bad example since it is very company specific.. Can we just use a generic, better example for the Resolution string "Check manager network.", "Replace failing Dimm.", etc ?

+1
Resolution property is read from D-Bus object, is there anything we can do here since it is suppose to be holding company specific resolution message?
Define a message registry to the intent of the redfish spec.  If it's OEM, build out the infrastructure for adding OEM registries and enabling them at compile time.

> Define a message registry to the intent of the redfish spec.  If it's OEM, build out the infrastructure for adding OEM registries and enabling them at compile time.

Redfish added this property, we have it on D-Bus, this is implementing this property. I guess I don't understand the need for a registry?
Right, but the LogService being modified doesn't have a MessageRegistry implemented, so isn't this code incorrect, because Resolution is supposed to match the MessageRegistry?

>  Resolution is supposed to match the MessageRegistry?

As I understand it from discussion when this was added, no. This Resolution is a free-form string intended only for humans to read. It is meant to have the implementation's "how to resolve this event", it isn't intended to match the MessageRegistry's Resolution and would supersede it as I understand it from discussion when this was added.

> LogService being modified doesn't have a MessageRegistry implemented, so isn't this code incorrect

This is separate  but I do agree, this LogService should have a MessageRegistry if it doesn't already
Ack
IMO we should bump all the LogEntries to the same version... But this wasn't true before. https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/54030 will fix this versioning crazyness.
Done
This matches what we have elsewhere, all schemas are the same versions.
I still think this is a bad example, oh well. A better example might be "Replace fan 0" or a lot of others.
Ack
I still have some concerns here about how this interoperates between dbus->bmcweb and stays maintainable, but I think we can answer that over time.
is there a limit to the length of the resolution? my confusion is, how will the other service know what kind of resolution is to be suggested.

This property is retrieved from D-Bus object, and used here as is. I'm not sure if there is a limit on the length while updating the Resolution property in D-Bus object. 

Regarding 'what kind of resolution is to be suggested": Per schema definition/description for the resolution, it's a free form and depends on the type of issue logged and how it was resolved(?). Here is the description from schema for Resolution:
'String="Used to provide suggestions on how to resolve the situation that caused the log entry."'
Ack
